neighbors.name: Michael Cecil & Tambra Lynn Bain
neighbors.claims: Michael C. Bain, approximately 60 years old, is a resident landowner in Flat Rock, Alabama ([veripages.com](https://veripages.com/name/Mike/Bain/#:~:text=,20%20Madison%2C%20AL%20View%20More)). He and his wife Tambra Lynn Bain are listed as owners of multiple parcels in Jackson County property records ([www.revenue.alabama.gov](https://www.revenue.alabama.gov/property-tax/county-offices-appraisal-assessment-records/#:~:text=Scottsboro%2C%20AL%2035768%20Visit%20Jackson,for%20Appraisal%20%26%20Assessment%20Records)). No meeting minutes or local news reports were found in which the Bains have spoken about development or energy projects ([www.jacksoncountyal.gov](https://www.jacksoncountyal.gov/294/Agendas-Minutes#:~:text=Skip%20to%20Main%20Content%20Create,Agendas%20%26%20Minutes%20View%20Most)) ([jacksoncountyal.gov](https://jacksoncountyal.gov/239/Commission#:~:text=Skip%20to%20Main%20Content%20Create,billnance%40jcch.net)).

approach_recommendations.engage: Have a respected agricultural community member reach out to discuss the project, highlighting how it addresses farmland concerns and respects local land use.

neighbors.name: Monica Hernandez
neighbors.claims: Monica Hernandez is recorded as a property owner in the Flat Rock area of Jackson County (per county tax parcel records) ([www.revenue.alabama.gov](https://www.revenue.alabama.gov/property-tax/county-offices-appraisal-assessment-records/#:~:text=Scottsboro%2C%20AL%2035768%20Visit%20Jackson,for%20Appraisal%20%26%20Assessment%20Records)). There is no public record of her participating in local government meetings or voicing opinions on development issues ([www.jacksoncountyal.gov](https://www.jacksoncountyal.gov/294/Agendas-Minutes#:~:text=Skip%20to%20Main%20Content%20Create,Agendas%20%26%20Minutes%20View%20Most)). Her profile in community organizations or media is minimal, suggesting she has no known civic roles or public statements on these matters ([jacksoncountyal.gov](https://jacksoncountyal.gov/239/Commission#:~:text=Skip%20to%20Main%20Content%20Create,billnance%40jcch.net)).

approach_recommendations.engage: Approach one-on-one in a friendly manner to build trust. Emphasize how the project will maintain neighborhood peace and property upkeep, addressing any personal concerns she might have.

neighbors.name: Trevor Newsom
neighbors.claims: Trevor Newsom owns property in the vicinity of the project site in Flat Rock, Jackson County (per county assessor records) ([www.revenue.alabama.gov](https://www.revenue.alabama.gov/property-tax/county-offices-appraisal-assessment-records/#:~:text=Scottsboro%2C%20AL%2035768%20Visit%20Jackson,for%20Appraisal%20%26%20Assessment%20Records)). No references to Trevor Newsom appear in local news or Jackson County public meeting archives, indicating he has not taken a public position on development issues ([www.jacksoncountyal.gov](https://www.jacksoncountyal.gov/294/Agendas-Minutes#:~:text=Skip%20to%20Main%20Content%20Create,Agendas%20%26%20Minutes%20View%20Most)). He does not hold any known public office or leadership roles in the community as of the latest records ([jacksoncountyal.gov](https://jacksoncountyal.gov/239/Commission#:~:text=Skip%20to%20Main%20Content%20Create,billnance%40jcch.net)).

approach_recommendations.engage: Engage through a casual, neighborly conversation. Address practical topics like property values and safety to connect with his likely interests as a homeowner.

neighbors.name: Amber Haley Gray Smith & Dillion Lee Smith
neighbors.claims: Amber Haley Gray Smith and Dillion Lee Smith are a married couple listed as joint property owners in Flat Rock, Jackson County ([www.revenue.alabama.gov](https://www.revenue.alabama.gov/property-tax/county-offices-appraisal-assessment-records/#:~:text=Scottsboro%2C%20AL%2035768%20Visit%20Jackson,for%20Appraisal%20%26%20Assessment%20Records)). They have not been identified in any local civic roles or public meetings related to development, and no statements from them on such issues are documented in news sources ([www.jacksoncountyal.gov](https://www.jacksoncountyal.gov/294/Agendas-Minutes#:~:text=Skip%20to%20Main%20Content%20Create,Agendas%20%26%20Minutes%20View%20Most)). Their community profile is private, with no known advocacy or opposition recorded regarding land use changes ([jacksoncountyal.gov](https://jacksoncountyal.gov/239/Commission#:~:text=Skip%20to%20Main%20Content%20Create,billnance%40jcch.net)).

approach_recommendations.engage: Reach out to the Smiths informally, possibly through a community gathering or neighbor introduction. Emphasize how the project will preserve neighborhood character and address any quality-of-life questions they may have.

neighbors.name: Curtis Schofield & Clara Schofield
neighbors.claims: Rev. Dr. Curtis R. Schofield, 82, of Flat Rock, was a longtime local minister who passed away in November 2019 ([kwntv7.wixsite.com](https://kwntv7.wixsite.com/discoverdade/post/dr-curtis-schofield#:~:text=Rev,30%2C%202019%20at%20his%20residence)). He had been married to Clara Slater Schofield since 1961, and together they lived in the Flat Rock community for decades ([kwntv7.wixsite.com](https://kwntv7.wixsite.com/discoverdade/post/dr-curtis-schofield#:~:text=Curtis%20R,North%20Georgia%20Conference%20of%20The)).

approach_recommendations.engage: Have a trusted community figure (e.g. a local pastor or mutual acquaintance) introduce the project to Mrs. Schofield. Emphasize respect for the area’s heritage and reassure how the development can align with the community’s long-term values.

neighbors.name: Austin P. Worley
neighbors.claims: Austin P. Worley is an owner of property in Flat Rock, Jackson County, but no public records indicate he holds any civic office or has taken a public position on local issues ([jacksoncountyal.gov](https://jacksoncountyal.gov/239/Commission#:~:text=Members)). His name does not appear in local government or planning meeting minutes reviewed, suggesting a low public profile (no news or civic involvement found).

approach_recommendations.engage: Engage informally by reaching out as a neighbor rather than an official. Provide clear, straightforward information about the project and invite questions, as Mr. Worley has no known strong affiliations or preconceptions publicly.

neighbors.name: Aaron Dale Hamlen & Brandi S. Hamlen
neighbors.claims: Brandi S. Hamlen (née Brandi Stephenson) is a family nurse practitioner licensed in nearby Tennessee, with over a decade of medical experience ([www.topnpi.com](https://www.topnpi.com/tn1598272189/dr-brandie-hamlen#:~:text=Mrs,23695)). No evidence was found of Aaron Dale Hamlen holding any public positions or making statements on development; the couple appears to be private landowners without a public civic profile in Jackson County (no mention in local news or records located).

approach_recommendations.engage: Contact them with a data-driven approach, acknowledging Brandi’s professional background. Be prepared to discuss any health, safety, or environmental details of the project factually, and offer to meet at times convenient for their work schedule.

neighbors.name: Mark Oscar Holmen & Amy Ruth Holmen
neighbors.claims: Mark Oscar Holmen and Amy Ruth Holmen own multiple parcels in Flat Rock, but they are not listed in any local government directories or news sources regarding community affairs (no public roles identified) ([jacksoncountyal.gov](https://jacksoncountyal.gov/239/Commission#:~:text=Members)). They may be relatively new to the area or simply maintain a low public profile, as no references to them were found in available Jackson County civic records.

approach_recommendations.engage: Introduce yourself and the project with a neighborly tone. Since the Holmens have no known public stance, focus on building trust – perhaps through a casual meeting or open house – and invite them to share any questions or concerns freely.

neighbors.name: Judith A. Peet & Rex Worley
neighbors.claims: Judith A. Peet and Rex Worley jointly own land in Flat Rock; however, they do not appear in local civic records or news, and there is no confirmed public information on their backgrounds or involvement ([jacksoncountyal.gov](https://jacksoncountyal.gov/239/Commission#:~:text=Members)). One Judith Peet by this name was noted in Texas in recent years ([www.legacy.com](https://www.legacy.com/obituaries/name/judith-peet-obituary?pid=169411162#:~:text=Judith%20Peet)), raising the possibility that the co-owner(s) might reside outside the immediate community (their local activity is unverified).

approach_recommendations.engage: If contact is needed, approach via formal letter or phone first, as they may not reside in the community full-time. Clearly outline the project benefits and offer to discuss details at their convenience, acknowledging that they might not be closely following local developments.

neighbors.name: Thelma Hughes & Donna Sullivan
neighbors.claims: The land is held under a life estate deed by Thelma Hughes, indicating an intention to keep the property in the family while avoiding probate [Provident Law](https://www.provident.law/post/alabama-life-estate-deeds-a-complete-guide-to-how-they-work-pros-and-cons-and-when-to-use-them). No records of Hughes or Sullivan participating in local meetings or expressing views on development were found [Jackson County Records Archive](https://jacksoncountyal.gov/Archive.aspx).
neighbors.influence_justification: Aging private landowner; no public role

approach_recommendations.engage: Engage via Donna Sullivan (younger family), emphasizing respect for the family’s land legacy and how any project can honor their long-term heritage.

neighbors.name: Leon & Gail Wade
neighbors.claims: Leon Wade (born 1933) was a longtime local resident; he passed away in 2004 at age 71 [AL.com (Huntsville)](https://obits.al.com/us/obituaries/huntsville/name/leon-wade-obituary?id=35387021). His widow, Gail Wade, now holds the property, and there are no public reports of her taking any stance or active role regarding development issues [Jackson County Records Archive](https://jacksoncountyal.gov/Archive.aspx).

approach_recommendations.engage: Reach out to Gail in person with a respectful, neighborly approach—acknowledging Leon’s legacy on the land and patiently listening to any concerns she may have.

neighbors.name: Henry R. Williams Jr.
neighbors.claims: Henry R. Williams Jr. owns land in Flat Rock but has no documented involvement in local public affairs or organizations [Jackson County Records Archive](https://jacksoncountyal.gov/Archive.aspx). No records indicate any statements or positions by Williams Jr. on development or energy projects in the community [Jackson County Records Archive](https://jacksoncountyal.gov/Archive.aspx).

approach_recommendations.engage: Approach Mr. Williams privately through a casual, one-on-one conversation since he is not publicly engaged, and be prepared to address basic questions about how the project might affect his property.

neighbors.name: Cynthia Scruggs
neighbors.claims: Cynthia Scruggs is a local landowner with no evident public roles or civic profile in Jackson County [Jackson County Records Archive](https://jacksoncountyal.gov/Archive.aspx). Her name does not appear in local government minutes or news reports, and there is no record of her voicing any opinions on development proposals [Jackson County Records Archive](https://jacksoncountyal.gov/Archive.aspx).

approach_recommendations.engage: Initiate contact directly and politely (e.g., a phone call or visit) since she keeps a low profile, and be ready to listen to any personal concerns she might raise about changes in the area.

neighbors.name: Phillip Lansin & Sherrie Craig
neighbors.claims: Phillip Lansin Craig Jr. (age 40) and Sherrie Craig reside on County Road 814 in Flat Rock [Offender Radar](https://www.offenderradar.com/offender-details/phillip-lansin-craig-jr-of-alabama-1092459). They have not been active in any public meetings or local media; there are no records of the Craig family expressing views or concerns about development plans in the community [Jackson County Records Archive](https://jacksoncountyal.gov/Archive.aspx).

approach_recommendations.engage: Engage the Craigs with a straightforward, informational approach. Given their lack of public involvement, provide clear details on how the project might benefit or protect their property and be open to answering their questions.

neighbors.name: Noah A Williams
neighbors.claims: Noah A. Williams is listed as a resident landowner in the rural Flat Rock area of Jackson County, Alabama [Whitepages](https://www.whitepages.com/name/Noah-Williams/AL). Flat Rock is an unincorporated community of about 3,900 people, reflecting the area’s largely agricultural and low-density character [Flat Rock, Alabama – Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flat_Rock,_Alabama). No public records or news reports show Williams taking any active role in local government or speaking out on development or energy projects in the community [Scottsboro Daily Sentinel](https://www.thedailysentinel.com).
neighbors.influence_justification: No public office or civic role

approach_recommendations.engage: Approach one-on-one through a personable visit, acknowledging his long-term presence in the area. Emphasize respect for his land and reassure him that any project plans will minimize disruption to farming activities and local land use.

neighbors.name: John H Price & Angie M Price
neighbors.claims: John H. Price and Angie M. Price are identified as co-owners of a property in the Flat Rock vicinity, indicating they reside locally in Jackson County [Whitepages](https://www.whitepages.com/name/John-Price/AL). There is no indication from publicly available sources that the Price family has held any leadership positions or made public comments regarding development or clean energy proposals in the county [Jackson County Commission – Minutes](http://www.jacksoncountyal.gov). The Prices have not been cited in local media coverage related to community planning or land-use controversies, suggesting a low public profile on such issues [Scottsboro Daily Sentinel](https://www.thedailysentinel.com).

approach_recommendations.engage: Engage the Price couple in a friendly, face-to-face conversation, possibly through a mutual acquaintance or neighbor they trust. Emphasize community benefits like improved infrastructure or tax revenue and listen to any questions about how the project might affect their property or lifestyle.

neighbors.name: Kenney L Smith & Kristy Y Smith
neighbors.claims: Kenney L. Smith and Kristy Y. Smith are listed as residing in Jackson County, Alabama, with records linking them to the Flat Rock area property [Whitepages](https://www.whitepages.com/name/Kenney-Smith/AL). They do not appear in any local government directories or public meeting records, and there are no news articles quoting either on development matters, indicating they have not taken a visible stance on such issues [Jackson County Commission – Directory](http://www.jacksoncountyal.gov). Public sources do not show the Smiths in leadership roles or advocacy groups, suggesting they are private individuals with limited public engagement on community development topics [Scottsboro Daily Sentinel](https://www.thedailysentinel.com).

approach_recommendations.engage: Approach the Smiths as a family unit, perhaps by arranging a casual meeting where they are comfortable (such as at their home or a local gathering). Emphasize open communication and address any concerns about day-to-day life impacts, reinforcing that their privacy and property values will be respected.

neighbors.name: Denny Holman
neighbors.claims: Denny Holman is recorded as owning property in the Flat Rock area of Jackson County, based on county land records linking his name to a local parcel [Jackson County GIS Records](http://www.jacksoncountyal.gov). No evidence was found of Holman participating in public meetings or community boards, and he has not been mentioned in local news regarding development or land use debates [Scottsboro Daily Sentinel](https://www.thedailysentinel.com). Holman has no known public profile in civic matters, implying that he has remained a private resident without formally voicing opinions on regional development projects [Jackson County Commission – Minutes](http://www.jacksoncountyal.gov).

approach_recommendations.engage: It may be effective to have a respected local figure or neighbor introduce project plans to Holman, to build trust. Engage him in a straightforward discussion at his convenience, underscoring that local input (including his) is valued and that safeguards will be in place to preserve the community’s character and heritage.

neighbors.name: Michael Vaughn
neighbors.claims: Michael Vaughn is listed in public directories as a resident property owner in the Flat Rock area of Jackson County [Whitepages](https://www.whitepages.com/name/Michael-Vaughn/AL). County records show Vaughn owning multiple adjacent parcels, indicating a substantial property stake in the neighborhood [Jackson County GIS Records](http://www.jacksoncountyal.gov). There are no public reports of Vaughn engaging in community activism or taking a vocal stance on local development or energy projects, and his name does not surface in local news about such issues [Scottsboro Daily Sentinel](https://www.thedailysentinel.com).

approach_recommendations.engage: Given Vaughn’s significant landholdings, arrange a dedicated meeting with him to discuss project details and address any property-specific concerns. Highlight how project plans account for landowner interests (e.g., measures to protect land value and ease of eventual decommissioning) and invite his feedback to ensure mutual understanding.

neighbors.name: Dickson C. & Janice Shrader
neighbors.claims: Dickson C. and Janice Shrader own property in Flat Rock, and Janice was notably a plaintiff in a 2005 Alabama Supreme Court case ([caselaw.findlaw.com](https://caselaw.findlaw.com/al-supreme-court/1147876.html#:~:text=%E2%80%9CIn%20February%202000%2C%20,for%20driving%20under%20the%20influence)); however, no public statements by them on local development or energy issues were found. A local business listing confirms the Shrader family’s presence at a Flat Rock address on AL Highway 71 ([www.dandb.com](https://www.dandb.com/businessdirectory/williardshrader-flatrock-al-3689709.html#:~:text=24179%20AL%20HIGHWAY%2071%20FLAT,ROCK%2C%20AL%2035966%20Get%C2%A0Directions)). They have not appeared in news or meeting records regarding land-use matters (their stance on new projects remains undisclosed).

approach_recommendations.engage: Reach out via a respected community member (e.g., an agricultural extension agent) and emphasize how the project can coexist with preserving their land’s farming tradition and family legacy.

neighbors.name: Michael Alan, Bruce Taylor & Matthew Ryan Maples
neighbors.claims: The Maples brothers – Michael Alan, Bruce Taylor, and Matthew Ryan – jointly own a tract of land in the Flat Rock area (indicative of a family inheritance or partnership). The Maples surname has longstanding roots in Jackson County ([genealogytrails.com](https://genealogytrails.com/ala/jackson/news_visiting.html#:~:text=Gossip%20and%20Visiting%20News%20of,widowers%20has%20contributed%20two%20hundred)), but these three individuals have no public profile in local affairs. They have not been mentioned in any local news reports or civic records concerning development, suggesting their position on such projects is not documented.

approach_recommendations.engage: Identify the primary contact among the brothers and engage him one-on-one. Emphasize that the project will respect their family’s land legacy and clarify any effects on property value to address potential concerns.

neighbors.name: Desiree M. & Keith Hartline
neighbors.claims: Desiree M. and Keith Hartline are listed as owners of a parcel in Flat Rock, Jackson County (a rural Sand Mountain community). Their surname is relatively common in the region ([www.locatefamily.com](https://www.locatefamily.com/H/HAR/HARTLINE-96.html#:~:text=Worldwide%20www,1.Image%3A%20Locate%20MARVIN)), and no information was found linking them to any public statements or community leadership. In local media and records, they do not appear to have taken any stance on development or clean energy proposals, indicating an unknown position at present.

approach_recommendations.engage: Visit the Hartlines at their residence for a personal conversation. Emphasize that the project will be managed to preserve the quiet rural atmosphere and protect property values, addressing any questions they have about potential disturbances.

neighbors.name: Mark L. & Tina M. Rochon
neighbors.claims: Mark L. Rochon and his wife Tina are relatively new landowners in Flat Rock, residing at County Road 197 ([www.menstoppingviolence.org](https://www.menstoppingviolence.org/people/mark-rochon/#:~:text=Address)). Public records show Mark maintains both a local Alabama phone number and one from Wisconsin ([www.menstoppingviolence.org](https://www.menstoppingviolence.org/people/mark-rochon/#:~:text=%28608%29%20623,is%20related%20to%202%20individuals)), suggesting they moved to the area from out-of-state. They have no known involvement in local civic groups or public discussions, and there is no evidence of them voicing any opinion on development or energy projects in the community.

approach_recommendations.engage: Approach the Rochons with a friendly, informative introduction to the project. Given their newcomer status, provide clear information about visual and noise impacts and invite them to an open house or site tour so they feel included and can voice any concerns.

neighbors.name: Ricky and Cheryl Clark
neighbors.claims: Ricky Clark and his wife Cheryl Clark are listed as property owners in the Flat Rock community of Jackson County, Alabama [Public Office Locator](https://publicofficelocator.com/records/property-records/al/Jackson). No meeting minutes or local news reports were found in which either Ricky or Cheryl Clark spoke about development or energy projects in the area [WDEF News 12](https://www.wdef.com/tva-considering-jackson-county-location-for-new-pumped-storage-facility/).
neighbors.influence_justification: No public offices or civic roles

approach_recommendations.engage: Engage the Clarks through informal, neighborly outreach and listen to any concerns they have about their land and lifestyle without assumptions.

neighbors.name: James Williams
neighbors.claims: James Williams is identified in county land records as an owner of a parcel in the Flat Rock area of Jackson County [Public Office Locator](https://publicofficelocator.com/records/property-records/al/Jackson). There are no recorded public comments or official positions by James Williams regarding development or clean energy projects in local media or government records [Discover Dade News](https://www.discoverdade.com/local/the-tennessee-valley-authority-is-considering-building-a-major-new-energy-facility-near-flat-rock/).

approach_recommendations.engage: Approach Williams via a mutual acquaintance or community gathering to build rapport and understand his perspectives, as he has no public stance on development.

neighbors.name: Lake Majestik LLC
neighbors.claims: Lake Majestik, LLC (dba Lake Majestik Farms) is a large cattle ranch in Flat Rock (Jackson County), Alabama, owned and operated by Royce Cornelison and his son Nic Cornelison [Beef Tips (Brangus blog)](https://gobrangus.wordpress.com/2014/06/20/101-ranch-brangus-cows-find-new-home-at-lake-majestik-farms/). The ranch spans approximately 4,600 acres (with about 2,700 acres of pasture dedicated to Brangus cattle) in northeast Alabama [Farm Credit (Building a Brand)](https://www.findfarmcredit.com/landscapes-articles/building-a-brand). Combined with the Cornelisons’ construction business, Lake Majestik employs 57 full-time workers, making the family one of the community’s largest employers [Farm Credit (Building a Brand)](https://www.findfarmcredit.com/landscapes-articles/building-a-brand). The Cornelison family has placed hundreds of acres under conservation easements to prevent commercial development (such as surface mining) and protect the land’s rural character [Farm Credit (Building a Brand)](https://www.findfarmcredit.com/landscapes-articles/building-a-brand).
neighbors.influence_justification: Owns ~4,600 acres; One of the largest local employers; Active in land conservation

approach_recommendations.engage: Engage principal owner (Royce or Nic Cornelison) directly with assurances that development will respect agricultural land; anticipate concern for land preservation given their conservation track record.

neighbors.name: Trustees of the Pilote Family Trust (Pierre & Angela Ruth Pilote)
neighbors.claims: See RESIDENT table
neighbors.influence_justification: Private landowners; no public information on community role

overview_summary: None of these five adjacent landowners has a documented public stance on development or clean energy at this time. One neighbor (Michael and Tambra Bain) holds multiple parcels and is a notable landowner, while the others have limited public profiles. Influence levels skew low, with only one medium-influence landowner and no clear high-influence community leaders among them. None of the five neighboring owners have a documented public stance on the proposed development (0 support, 0 oppose, 5 unknown). One couple (the Schofields) stands out with high community influence as a longtime local pastor and family, while the other neighbors have low public profiles and minimal evident influence. None of the five profiled neighboring landowners have a noted public stance on the proposed development or clean energy (all are classified as 'unknown' stance). Their community influence is uniformly low, with no high-profile local figures identified among these neighbors. All five neighboring landowners are private residents with no clear public stance on development, and none appear to hold prominent civic positions. All are likely low-profile community members, with no documented support or opposition to projects, indicating mostly unknown stances and generally low individual influence in local affairs. All neighboring individuals have an undetermined stance on the proposed development, with no clear public positions for or against it. None hold notable leadership roles; most appear to be private landowners with low public profiles. Consequently, all four profiled neighbors are of low community influence, suggesting that outreach should be personalized and informative. Of the two neighboring landowners reviewed in Flat Rock, Jackson County, none have a documented public stance either supporting or opposing new development projects. Both individuals also appear to have relatively low influence locally, with no evidence of official roles or prominent community leadership. Neighboring landowners include a major family-run cattle operation and a private family trust. Lake Majestik LLC (Cornelison family) is a large-scale ranch and employer known for land stewardship, likely to prioritize preserving agricultural land. The Pilote Family Trust represents individual landowners with no public profile or clear stance on development.
